28.60.text: Hello. 28 teams qualified to appear in this series.

32.00.text: 12 fell by the wayside during the first round.

34.72.text: Seven more have bitten the dust during this second round,

38.08.text: which ends tonight. Only one place remains in the quarterfinals

41.28.text: and both tonight's teams want it.

43.72.text: Well, they think they do now.

45.20.text: The four from St John's College, Oxford, achieved

47.40.text: one of the strongest scores of the first round

49.72.text: when they beat Bristol University by 255 points to 125.

54.44.text: They missed very little and did well

56.52.text: on dungeons and dragons in English literature and biblical book clouds.

60.72.text: And they were very happy with some gruesome depictions

64.16.text: of what Judith did to Holofernes.

66.36.text: With an average age of 19, let's meet the St John's team again.

70.88.text: Hi, my name is Alex Harries.

72.24.text: I'm originally from South Wales and I'm reading History.

75.60.text: Hello, my name is Charlie Clegg, I'm from Glasgow

80.56.text:
- This is their captain. 
- Hi, my name is Angus Russell,

83.44.text: I'm from Mill Hill in north London and I study History and Russian.

88.16.text: I'm from Uxbridge in Middlesex and I'm reading Chemistry.

96.28.text: The team from Queen's, Belfast, maintained a steady lead

99.80.text: throughout their first-round match against Sussex University,

106.68.text: They may need to brush up their Shakespeare,

109.12.text: but they recognised Edmund Burke, WH Auden

111.76.text: and the Velvet Underground as if they were all old pals.

115.28.text: With an average age of 28, let's meet the Queen's, Belfast, team again.

120.64.text: Hi, I'm Alistair Mallon from Belfast.

123.20.text: I'm studying a Masters degree in Irish Studies.

128.92.text: I'm originally from Ripley in Derbyshire

130.96.text: and I'm studying for a Masters in Irish Literature.

135.64.text: Hello, my name is Jack Ruddy, I'm from Dorset and I'm reading History.

139.60.text: Hi, I'm Charlie Shimmins, I'm from the Isle of Man

142.40.text: and I'm studying International Politics and Conflict Studies.

149.88.text: OK, shall we just get on with it? Fingers on buzzers.

154.88.text: What word denotes in general terms a receptacle for a grocery item,

159.36.text: in computing, a decoy website to draw hackers or spammers,

163.20.text: in espionage, a form of recruitment through seduction,

170.04.text: No. And you lose five points.

174.72.text: a place that draws a large number of visitors.

183.64.text: OK, you get a set of bonuses on the human figure in British art.

189.04.text: Firstly, a living human figure sleeping in a glass vitrine

192.56.text: comprises the work The Maybe, first displayed in 1995

196.44.text: and exhibited again in 2013 in New York's Museum of Modern Art.

201.04.text: Which actress was the figure on display?

206.16.text:
- Tilda Swinton? 
- Did she go in for things like this? 
- Go for it?

213.20.text: 100 life-sized human figures created by Antony Gormley

216.72.text: for a work entitled Another Place took up permanent residence in 2007

231.76.text: I thought it was Crosby beach. That's Merseyside.

237.84.text: Two living human figures painted gold and miming to a song

241.48.text: by Flanagan and Allen comprise the Singing Sculpture of 1969,

245.44.text: devised and performed by which artists?

251.16.text:
- Gilbert and George. 
- Correct. 10 points for this.

253.84.text: "His philosophy is so odd that one would not have expected him

257.00.text: "to be able to get sane men to accept it, but he did.

259.96.text: "He set it out with so much obscurity

262.04.text: "that people thought it must be profound."

264.48.text: These words of Bertrand Russell refer to which philosopher?

267.56.text: Born in Stuttgart in 1770, he's especially noted

270.68.text: for his three-stage process of dialectical reasoning.

280.24.text: Your first bonuses, Queen's, are on apps.

285.72.text: which app for decluttering Gmail inboxes

288.24.text: was bought by the cloud storage firm Dropbox

290.88.text: for a rumoured 100 million the following month?

302.76.text: which app has been called a mashup of Twitter and Snapchat

305.92.text: and allows users to type out a short confessional message,

309.56.text: overlay it on a related image and share it anonymously?

320.28.text: Allowing users to trade text, pictures and videos

323.32.text: over their smartphones, which mobile messaging service

326.84.text: was bought by Facebook for 19 billion in February 2014?

338.60.text: In Jane Austen's Mansfield Park, Mr Rushworth takes a house there.

342.16.text: In Shaw's Pygmalion, Henry Higgins lived at 27a.

345.56.text: At number 50, Elizabeth Barrett was kept a virtual prisoner by her father...

355.52.text: These bonuses, Queen's, are on sociology.

358.52.text: Coined in 1922 by the US sociologist William Ogburn,

363.00.text: what two-word term refers to the gap that develops

375.36.text:
- Culture gap. 
- It's the cultural lag, is the term.

379.40.text: Secondly, what term was introduced by US sociologist William G Sumner

386.16.text: He defined it as the view of things

388.12.text: in which one's own group is the centre of everything

391.12.text: and all others are scaled and rated with reference to it?

410.32.text: Abbreviated to TCK, what term was coined by Dr Ruth Hill Useem

416.64.text: and refers to a young person who spent a significant part

420.08.text: of their developmental years outside their parents' culture?

433.56.text: We'll take a picture round now.

435.48.text: You're going to see a map showing the migration of a specific group

440.16.text: a large-scale movement of peoples across the territory

443.12.text: and former territories of the moribund Western Roman Empire.

446.36.text: 10 points if you can give the name by which the group

449.16.text: who made the indicated migration are commonly known.

460.12.text: OK, Queen's, you're going to see

462.08.text: three more migrations now for your picture bonuses,

464.56.text: this time all made by Germanic tribes

466.60.text: into the territories of the collapsing Western Roman Empire.

469.64.text: Five points for each tribe you can name. Firstly...

482.28.text:
- The Visigoths. 
- That is correct, yes. Secondly...

497.96.text:
- The Goths. 
- No, that's the Vandals.

499.92.text: You can see they took Carthage there. And finally...

507.56.text: It's either the Angles or the Saxons.

510.08.text: Or is it the Jutes? Jutes?

512.88.text:
- Jutes? 
- It is the Jutes, yes. 10 points for this.

515.96.text: Examples being found in Texas, Florida, Alaska, Oklahoma and Idaho,

521.52.text: what informal term denotes a narrow strip of territory

524.76.text: with a land border on at least two sides,

527.16.text: extending out from the geographical body of the state?

529.88.text: The term refers to a part of a household...?

537.76.text: You could retake the lead if you get these bonuses.

542.44.text: Which mythical beast is usually described as having

545.08.text: the head of a man, the body of a lion and the tail of a dragon or scorpion?

549.00.text: Its name appears in the title of the second volume

551.72.text: of Robertson Davies's the Deptford Trilogy.

560.48.text: In Greek mythology, which child-eating monster is a serpent

564.04.text: with the head and breasts of a woman?

566.00.text: She is also the title character of a poem by Keats.

576.40.text: Which mythical beast has the head and four legs of a horse

579.48.text: and the body and tail of a dolphin or fish?

583.68.text: in the sculpture of the Trevi Fountain in Rome.

590.12.text: There's one in Rockefeller as well.

599.12.text:
- It's like a mermaid, but it's not. 
- I'll go with Triton.

602.76.text: No, it's a Hippocamp or Hippocampus. 10 points for this.

608.96.text: Vela and the Crab all hold what type of object

612.08.text: that typically emits short bursts of radio

615.12.text: and other electromagnetic radiation in a regular pattern?

624.96.text: You get the lead and a set of bonuses on mathematics.

627.92.text: What is the lowest order of polynomial

630.32.text: for which no general solution can be expressed

633.20.text: in terms of simple arithmetical operations?

649.28.text:
- One? 
- No, it's the fifth, the quintic.

652.20.text: The proof that the quintic is not solvable algebraically

655.52.text: is attributed jointly to the Italian Paolo Ruffini

660.52.text: In group theory, commutative groups are named after him.

670.08.text:
- Nominate Sowood. 
- Schoenflies? 
- No, it's Abel.

675.56.text: which French mathematician gives his name to the class of groups

679.28.text: with which the general quintic equation can be associated?

688.64.text: I think it's a bit late for Pascal, isn't it?

695.92.text:
- Try De Moivre. 
- De Moivre? 
- Yes.

699.16.text:
- De Moivre? 
- No, it's Galois. 10 points for this.

701.76.text: What precise three-word term did President Eisenhower coin

704.88.text: to describe the Alliance of Armed Forces, government agencies...?

708.56.text:
- Military industrial complex. 
- Correct. Well done.

713.80.text: Your bonuses are on cities in the Rhone Valley.

717.44.text: Firstly for five, which city provided inspiration for Vincent van Gogh

720.92.text: when he settled there for 15 months?

722.92.text: His works from that period include Starry Night Over The Rhone

734.00.text: Which town between Valence and Orange

736.48.text: is a major centre for the production of nougat?

752.24.text:
- It's not Avignon, is it? 
- Avignon?

756.24.text: Finally, from 1309 until 1377, which city on the Rhone

760.12.text: was the residence of the Popes during their exile from Rome?

763.16.text: It remained in papal hands until the Revolution.

767.28.text: We'll take a music round now.

769.08.text: For your music starter, you'll hear a piece of popular music.

772.04.text: For 10 points, give me the name of the singer you hear.

778.40.text:
- Johnny Cash. 
- It is Johnny Cash, yes.

784.16.text: Performing there God's Gonna Cut You Down

786.60.text: or Run On For A Long Time, a traditional song of unknown origin.

789.72.text: Your music bonuses are three more examples

792.08.text: of popular music artists performing traditional songs.

795.44.text: I want the band or the artist you hear in each case.

798.64.text: Firstly for five, both of these performers,

801.00.text: the song's roots can be traced back to a 17th-century British ballad.

807.16.text: # Tell her to make me a cambric shirt... #

816.04.text: of this version of an 18th-century Scottish song.

828.96.text: # A little bird lit down on Henry Lee... #

833.36.text:
- Is it Cerys Matthews? 
- OK, with Tom Jones?

836.36.text:
- Probably not. 
- No, they did duet together. 
- OK.

839.52.text:
- Tom Jones and Cerys Matthews. 
- No, it's Nick Cave and PJ Harvey.

843.08.text: Finally, this band performing a 19th-century Appalachian folk song.

847.48.text: # My girl, my girl, don't lie to me

853.68.text: # Tell me where did you sleep last night?

860.28.text: # In the pines, in the pines

863.56.text: # Where the sun don't ever shine... #

866.60.text:
- Bon Jovi? 
- No, that's Nirvana. 10 points for this.

870.28.text: Which decade saw the capture of Beijing

874.48.text: In Japan, the Dutch began trading from the island of Dejima in Nagasaki Bay,

879.16.text: while in England the King was executed.

887.20.text: St John's, your bonuses are on words that appear in the surnames

892.92.text: For example, "man" and "ant" in Hilary Mantell.

896.12.text: In each case, listen to the definition and give the name

898.64.text: of the author in whose surname the defined word appears.

903.04.text: Firstly, a term by Rudyard Kipling that includes the line

906.48.text: "Talk with crowds and keep your virtue."

911.88.text:
- Are they all Booker prize-winners? 
- Yeah, Booker prize-winners.

925.28.text: Shall we try something like that?

930.44.text: You got "If", of course, from where the lines are taken.

933.20.text: The surname of an author born near Birmingham in 1961.

936.76.text: His novels include The Rotters' Club and What A Carve Up!

948.04.text:
- Is "if" in it? 
- No, I don't think so.

955.00.text: Oh, gosh, what? Will Self, is it?

961.08.text: No, it's... Jonathan Coe was the author.

963.12.text: JM Coetzee was the Booker prize-winner.

965.24.text: Finally, the first name of the elder of the brothers Grimm

968.12.text: and of the man became President of South Africa in 2009.

972.00.text:
- Jacob. Howard Jacobson. Howard Jacobson. 
- Correct.

977.76.text: Answer soon as your name is called.

979.72.text: What date corresponds to the 183rd day of a year

983.16.text: that is not a leap year, therefore marking its midpoint?

997.20.text: Did you just work that out? It's pretty good.

999.96.text: Right, here are your bonuses, they're on British birds, St John's.

1003.80.text: Caprimulgus europaeus has what common name

1006.96.text: reflecting its nocturnal habits and distinctive churring call?

1010.64.text: It's also known as the goat sucker or fern owl.

1023.68.text:
- Yeah, nighthawk is a bird. 
- OK.

1026.64.text:
- Nighthawk. 
- No, it is the nightjar.

1029.32.text: Also named for its distinctive cry,

1031.28.text: which summer visitor is similar in form to the nightjar?

1034.56.text: It's a brood parasite on species such as reed warblers and dunnocks.

1039.24.text:
- The cuckoo is a parasite on warblers. 
- Cuckoo?

1043.80.text: With its pointed wings and long tail, the nightjar resembles

1046.68.text: which common raptor often seen near road verges?

1058.96.text:
- Kite. 
- No, it's smaller than that, it's a kestrel or windhover.

1062.16.text: 10 points for this. Alluding to William Paley's argument from design,

1065.72.text: what term did Richard Dawkins coin for the title of his...?

1074.40.text: Your bonuses are on film adaptations of a play by Shakespeare.

1078.44.text: With its action transposed to feudal Japan,

1082.00.text: Akira Kurosawa's 1957 film Throne Of Blood

1085.12.text: is an adaptation of which of Shakespeare's tragedies?

1093.56.text: With the tag line "greasy spoon, bloody murder",

1096.96.text: which 2001 adaptation of Macbeth relocates the events and characters

1101.44.text: to a Pennsylvania burger bar in the 1970s?

1104.88.text:
- Scotland PA. 
- OK, I'll go with that.

1109.68.text: Which Polish-born director collaborated with the critic Kenneth Tynan

1113.72.text: on the screenplay for his 1971 film version of Macbeth?

1123.36.text: Right, there's plenty of time for you to make up ground, Queen's.

1126.88.text: We'll take a second picture round.

1128.64.text: For your picture starter you'll see a painting by a Dutch artist.

1132.28.text: 10 points if you can identify the artist.

1142.88.text: That's part of the collection bought by the British government

1146.64.text: in 1824 from the private collector John Julius Angerstein

1150.12.text: to form a basis for the new National Gallery.

1152.96.text: Your picture bonuses, three more paintings from that founding acquisition,

1156.68.text: all of which remain in the National Gallery today.

1159.12.text: In each case I simply need you to identify the artist.

1162.16.text: Firstly for five, this French artist.

1166.88.text: I'm fairly sure that's Claude Lorraine.

1168.88.text:
- His Embarkation Of Daedalus. 
- Nominate Clegg.

1189.96.text: Rape Of The Sabine Women, yes, well done. 10 points for this.

1193.08.text: Described by Bill Clinton as the Woodstock of the mind,

1196.00.text: which major event has been held annually since 1988

1199.08.text: in a town in the Black Mountains of the Brecon Beacons National Park?

1202.96.text:
- The Hay Literary Festival. 
- The Hay Festival is correct, yes.

1208.28.text: You get a set of bonuses, Queen's, Belfast, on first names.

1211.76.text: Which girl's name rose in popularity following events

1214.36.text: in the Outer Hebrides in the aftermath of the Battle of Culloden?

1217.52.text: It's also that of the Roman goddess of the spring.

1224.64.text: Which name comes from that of the mythological lover of Apollo,

1228.12.text: killed by Zephyrus? His spilt blood grew into a flower.

1239.28.text: Which floral name links the son of the Pooters in The Diary Of A Nobody

1243.40.text: and the gentleman burglar created by Maurice Leblanc

1246.68.text: as a given name and surname respectively?

1252.88.text:
- Lupin? 
- Lupin is correct, yes. Another starter question.

1258.04.text: the large mammal Ursus spelaeus has what two-word common name?

1262.56.text: It became extinct during the Pleistocene Epoch.

1266.92.text:
- Woolly mammoth. 
- No. Queen's, one of you buzz.

1274.76.text: No, it's the cave bear. 10 points for this.

1277.28.text: To the east of Stockport in greater Manchester,

1279.52.text: the confluence of the rivers Etherow, Goyt and Tame form...

1283.24.text:
- The Mersey. 
- The Mersey is correct, yes.

1288.64.text: Your bonuses are on Rhodes Scholars, Queen's, Belfast.

1292.20.text: In each case, name the person from the description.

1294.64.text: Firstly, an astronomer, who in the words of one author in 1925,

1297.96.text: released findings that ultimately established that

1300.88.text: "our universe was 1,000 trillion times larger than previously believed,

1305.68.text: "filled with myriad galaxies like our own."

1317.48.text: Born in 1907, a historian who greatly expanded the field of Chinese studies,

1322.16.text: he was the co-author of East Asia: Tradition And Transformation,

1326.08.text: a standard text on the subject.

1333.84.text:
- Pass. 
- That was Fairbank. John King Fairbank.

1336.60.text: Finally, a social critic and activist,

1338.96.text: the author of The Beauty Myth and the 2008 work

1341.56.text: Give Me Liberty: A Handbook For American Revolutionaries.

1353.68.text:
- Pass. 
- That's Naomi Wolf. 10 points for this.

1357.08.text: In human anatomy, the adjective popliteal or poplitic

1360.92.text: refers to the indentation between the tendons behind which joint?

1368.04.text:
- Knee? 
- The knee is correct, yes.

1372.68.text: Your bonuses, St John's, are on schools of art now.

1375.84.text: Firstly, for five, which village in Cornwall gives its name

1378.84.text: to the group of artists including Stanhope Forbes and Walter Langley,

1382.40.text: who worked there in the late 19th and early 20th century?

1385.48.text:
- St Ives. 
- No, that was a bit later. It's the Newlyn School.

1389.16.text: What name is given to a group of artists who specialise

1392.12.text: in scenes of daily life in New York around 1900?

1394.76.text: Its members included George Bellows, Robert Henri and John Sloan.

1401.60.text: Named after a village near Fontainebleau,

1403.76.text: which group of artists included Jean-Francois Millet and Theodore Rousseau

1407.60.text: and is regarded as a forerunner of the Impressionist school?

1422.40.text:
- Sevres? 
- No, it's the Barbizon School. 10 points for this.

1425.96.text: Which French writer's works include semi-autobiographical accounts

1429.72.text: of his experiences in Mettray Penal Colony and Fontevrault Prison

1436.12.text:
- Camus. 
- No. You lose five points.

1439.92.text: ..the 1946 work The Miracle Of The Rose.

1445.04.text:
- Sartre? 
- No, it's Jean Genet. 10 points for this starter question.

1449.36.text: What three-letter word results from expressing in Roman numerals

1452.64.text: the smallest prime number greater than 1,000?

1468.92.text: Lining most surfaces and cavities of the body, what simple tissue consists

1472.72.text: of closely packed cells in sheets with little inter-cellular material?

1483.40.text:
- Cartilage. 
- No, it's the epithelium or epithelia.

1486.72.text: From the Latin for scale, what term describes

1488.92.text: the part of the epithelium that consists of flattened cells?

1492.48.text: It is sometimes known as pavement.

1504.48.text: where the width and height of its cells are broadly similar?

1514.00.text: Three minutes to go, 10 points for this. Answer promptly.

1516.72.text: Of the three US states whose names contain only four letters,

1533.12.text: St John's, your bonuses are on Russian rivers.

1535.96.text: Which major river flows from its sources in the mountains

1539.08.text: near Lake Baikal to the mouth of its delta on the Laptev Sea?

1545.00.text: I think it's the Irtysh. Or the Ob.

1548.24.text:
- Irtysh? 
- Yeah, it goes into Lake Baikal.

1553.64.text: Rising in the Republic of Tuva

1555.16.text: and flowing for more than 3,400 kilometres to the Kara Sea,

1558.96.text: which river has a name deriving from the words for "great river"

1573.36.text: Come on, let's have it, please.

1575.08.text:
- Havaria? 
- No, that's the Yenisei River.

1577.32.text: Finally, which river rises to the south-east of Moscow

1580.48.text: and flows for more than 1,800 kilometres into the Sea of Azov?

1589.68.text:
- The Volga. 
- No, that's the Don. 10 points for this.

1592.92.text: FitzClarence was the surname given to the ten illegitimate children

1596.96.text: born between 1794 and 1807 to the actress...?

1602.16.text:
- George IV. The Prince Regent. 
- No, I'm afraid you lose five points.

1605.88.text: ..to the actress Dorothea Jordan and which future king?

1610.20.text:
- William IV. 
- William IV, or the Duke of Clarence as he was at the time.

1617.32.text: Your bonuses are on James Bond novels by authors other than Ian Fleming.

1622.28.text: Firstly, who wrote the 2008 novel Devil May Care?

1628.52.text:
- Sebastian Faulks. 
- Sebastian Faulks is right.

1631.32.text: Who was the author of the 1968 novel Colonel Sun?

1634.40.text: You may give the author's name

1636.04.text: or the pen name under which it was published.

1647.20.text: That was Kingsley Amis writing as Robert Markham.

1649.68.text: Finally, who wrote the 2013 James Bond story, Solo?

1658.80.text:
- I'm not sure. 
- Charlie Higson did the young Bond series.

1664.44.text: No, it was William Boyd. 10 points for this.

1666.64.text: In Book One of Paradise Lost,

1668.84.text: what name did Milton coin for Satan's capital?

1678.16.text: Your bonuses are on the official nicknames of US states.

1681.36.text: In each case, listen to the description and give both... GONG

1684.72.text: And at the gong, Queen's, Belfast, have 100,

1693.04.text: Well, you had some pretty impressive interventions, Queen's,

1696.04.text: but you weren't good enough. These guys were on pretty good form tonight.

1699.20.text: So we'll have to say goodbye to you,

1701.12.text: but thank you very much for joining us.

1703.08.text: St John's, another terrific performance from you.

1705.32.text: We look forward to seeing you in the quarterfinals. Do join us then.

1708.44.text: I hope you can join us for the first of the quarterfinals next time

1711.32.text:
- but until then, it's goodbye from Queen's, Belfast. 
- Goodbye.

1714.36.text:
- It's goodbye from St John's College, Oxford. 
- Goodbye.

1717.04.text: And it's goodbye from me. Goodbye.
